content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												Lego Batman 2 was quite an achievement in Traveller's Tales' long-running Lego series with its large sandbox city filled with tons of collectibles and an equally large roster of colorful and varied heroes and villains. The storytelling aspect got a major writing overhaul by officially leaving the 'mime' humor behind by bringing in the A-team of voicework that made the game able to tell its own, unique story rather than simply act out a film's plot.Lego Marvel Super Heroes does what any sequel should and expands on everything its predecessor was and more.The sandbox of New York city is positively ginormeous and filled to the brim with personality, be it in the faithfully constructed Marvel landmarks or the various quirky side-quest granting citizens and puzzles. There are even secret stages to uncover if you search hard enough!The stages themselves have also taken a boost and are more layered, boasting strong location variety and quirky creativety. The creators also managed to finally truly nail the length of the stages so that they go on just long enough while throwing encounters and thrills at you around every corner to satisfywithout overstaying their welcome and just becoming stale.There are boss-fights a plenty in this game, even more than ever beforeand, while they are all fairly unique, few bosses actually change their tactics mid-fight,leaving what will initially strike many players as impressive and fun fights to become rather repetitive by the time they land the final hit.One thing that has taken a hit since the last game, however, is the combat.Unlike Lego Batman 2, which used a miniaturized version of the Arkham games' combat by allowing you to unleash special moves when your multiplier was high enough, in this game, those moves now just randomly happen.It certainly adds visual flair to the fights, but feels even more button-mashy than previous incarnations.Still, all is not lost, most characters now have unique moves that can be triggered by pressing B at any time (it used to be a generic grab-button in LB2), which does add some much needed variety. Speaking of variety, Lego Marvel Super Heroes boast one of the largest rosters in any Lego game and all the characters look, move, fight and feel like they should, which is a large plus for comic-book fans who can finally say their favorite characters have a game that does them justice.Unfortunately, this game is not without glitches,on a 100% playthrough, you're sure to run into some sooner or later.In my experience, I had situations were certain NPCs wouldn't load,NPCs wouldn't jump into your Taxi and the game wouldn't accept 100% until I re-beat the final stage again. In all cases, simply continuously resetting the game until it worked eventually prevailed,so luckily, there is no truly gamebreaking glitch that'll make 100% impossible.Ultimately, Lego Marvel Super Heroes is superior to its predecessors in almost every way,though, as it IS more of a simple (unless you set your eyes upon the lofty goal of achieving 100% completion) and quirky puzzle-game by nature,I'd recommend to pay with caution if you expect something grander.However! If you like the Marvel universe, collect-a-tons that keep you playing long after the credits roll, puzzles or large sandboxes to roam around in and explore,then you can do little better than Lego Marvel Super Heroes.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 13, 2016
Basic Information:Title: Lego Jurassic WorldDeveloper: TT Games LtdPublisher: Warner Bros. Interactive EntertainmentGenre: Action, AdventureLEGO Marvel Super Heroes is by far the biggest LEGO game to date, and not just in map size. Almost every Marvel character you can think of is in this game, and it is very obvious that the game's developers were big fans of the Marvel universe, as no expense was spaired this time. However, although this game may seem like an open world LEGO adventure, don't be fooled. The truth is that the majority of the gameplay including all of the story levels are linear. The only time that this game is open world is when you are not in a level, and even then you are restricted to a very small city that feels a little empty. Saying that, the actual levels, although linear are quite fun, in the same way that every LEGO game is fun. One of the worst parts about this game are the controls, playing this game with a keyboard is a chore and doesn't feel right. This problem is easily solved by using a controller. After the main story has been completed there are hundreds of other things you can do and you will never find yourself bored whilst playing the game. There are some bugs, like all LEGO games but they aren't game breaking and wont limit your experiance in a major way. In conclusion, I would recommend this game, but only if you have a controller which you can plug in and use. Luckily, many controller brands are supported in all LEGO games, atleast on the Steam store.Scores:Graphics: 8/10Gameplay: 8/10Audio: 7/10Story: 9/10Overall: 8/10Reviewed by Elliott Marc Jones for Redacted Network's Curator page.

												First time playing was on Xbox and it was very fun! So fun infact I got it for PC on a steam summer sale.Rating: 9.5/10What I like: Simple enough for people new to video games & fun enough to keep your interest.For such a simple style of game, graphically, this game is stunning! The lighting and water effects are beautiful and well done, but it's lego bricks! Ha ha! If you have played any lego games, you know they are goofy and fun with essentially the same main story arc as their theme. This is by far one of the best lego games I have ever played and is one of the first that implemented actual voice acting, which in my opinion was a good move and they cast some great voice actors. Nick Fury sounds just like Sam Jackson and a few voices are actually the same actors from the films such as Agent Phil Coulson.What I don't like: The controls are a bit wonky. Great controller support, but the standard control set up is awkward and does not seem very practical when in game. I have not seen an in game option to reassign key bindings, but that would be wonderful!

												I had a fun time playing this game. If you have played a "Lego" game before, you know what ypur up for. And thats a great action adventure game with some puzzle sholving. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
												LEGO Marvel Superheores is a great game. I really like this game, and recommend it to anyone that likes Lego and Marvel. Has a huge range of characters and has a large free-roam area to do what ever you want in. the only problem, only two boats, but that's not a big deal. The game can be a bit glitchly at times but keeps you entertained for hours. When i mean glitchy, i mean real glitchy. I found this glitch with Thor, where i turned into the citizen? And i found two spots where i could go under the city and onto the islands in the background? I also was on the other side of the bridge, where i couldn't go. What?When they say there are a lot of characters, they are correct, because there are something like over 100 playable, and thats without the DLC. The DLC was pretty good, giving you extra vehicles and characters, but most of their abilities were the same as other characters, so i recommend waiting until they are on special as they are not worth their full price. The steam achievments are also good and provide something else to do in the free-roam city. Just a warning, there are cheat codes, but the one for the hulkbuster prevents you from getting 100%, so i don't recommend using them.There are a lot of bonus levels, which some give a good laugh. Suitable for all ages, even little kittens. Score 9.5/10

Posted: September 17, 2016
												I can't remember hints being THIS annoying in other LEGO games. In Marvel Superheroes, you can't turn them off, and they take away any semblence of difficulty. You basically just run around and do exactly what the hints say. What's the point of playing except to add "punch everything that looks even remotely breakable" to the "follow the hints" gameplay?edit:I booted up my old LEGO Lord of the Rings game on Wii, and sure enough, there was nothing but very basic hints when you start up, like "B to attack". I approached a spot with sparkles and got 0 hints at all. No handholding, telling me what kind of character to use or what substance I was battling. I adored LEGO Lord of the Rings, and I wish Lego Marvel Superheroes had a "no hints" option (seems SUPER simple to implement).

number of helpful: 8 of 16 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												A very fun game when I didn't think it would be. I figured it got good reviews and the gameplay looked good so I would give it a try for $5. I have put a lot of time into it now and always am having fun. It can be very cryptic at times during a stage until you get the hang of what the game wants you to do exactly, which for a Lego game shouldn't be so difficult to figure out basic things to advance a level. I have put a bunch of time into going around the city and unlocking new guys and replaying stages on free play to unlock the level secrets. One big problem with the game that I did not figure out until I googled it was how to switch characters while in the city. After coming out of a mission it locks you into two characters and you can't hold Y to switch. Until I researched it, I had no idea that I was supposed to first go to a blue vehicle/character machine to set the game to after you switch that way to then allow you to switch simply by holding Y. It makes no sense and should not be that way. There are a ton of characters to unlock, 100 total I think, a lot I've never even heard of. I just use Hulk and Human Torch most of the time because Hulk can run faster than any other character and can smash up levels and enemies much quicker, and the Human Torch is the easiest go-to flying character on the screen when I can't remember exactly who can fly and who can't. I just unlocked my favorite Marvel guy of all time, Magneto, and thankfully he is fun to play as. The game also has my four other favorites as well; Juggernaut, Carnage, Venom, and of course Hulk. Yay!Only Marvel super fans will want to sit and unlock all 100 chars, although needless to say, there is so much to do in this game that I have almost 30 hours in and still haven't unlocked all the characters. I haven't even finished story mode yet because I have spent so much time running around the city and unlocking things.The combat, sound, music, effects, story, script, and graphics are all fitting of a Lego game. It looks and performs very smoothly. The only real major complaint I have with the game is that the flying controls for some characters suck bad. I know exactly how the flying controls work, they just simply suck♥♥♥♥♥ The characters that don't control well are the ones who have the ability to fly fast, which so far have been Thor, Human Torch, Iron Man, and Wizard. So it's only true for a few characters, but still annoying since it is the fastest way in the game to get around.Of all the more challenging action and permadeath games I play, this is a nice casual game I can just relax and play without worrying about dying. Probably the most fun casual action game I've ever played. Worth it on sale but also at regular price if it is $20 or less.9/10 very good relaxing fun

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												This game is an absolute blast.   My son and I play, but he plays mostly..   There's a lot to do, but the only minor thing I hate is having to GRIND to get DEADPOOL.  .    Still, there are lots of characters to tickle your nostalga bone.. okay that was a weird way to put it, but none the less you'll feel pretty cool being your favorites from Marvel.   The Lego games in general are great at teaching kids the basics of gaming.   The puzzles are great for kids, and learning to fill up a meter , find bricks, and running around with a pal is always fun..    Adults will have a great time too.  The lego characters are funny and the story is goofy.. Just a good time ...again especially if you have children.. My son is 5, he's been playing the Lego games since 3.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												This game may have some glitches but its still a REALLY fun game. worth the $30. TONS of marvel characters and unlockables, endless replayability with side quests in a lego GTA type open world. So far i have only 1 DLC and its my personal favorite so i reccomend that too. Still even great games have downfalls and this is game has a few irritating ones;1.broken flying controls (i use an xbox controller) the whole flying mechanic is based on a 2 button system and way too complicated2.repetitive gameplay..its a lego game so all you're doing is walking around each mission trying to complete it and blowing everything up along the way for bits.3.weak and pointless bad guys. this isnt that big of a deal because its a gema made for the younger gamers, but for hardcore to casual gamers (like as myself) this is a big one because each level is WAY too easy with boring combat against weak underpowered baddies.as a result i give this a 8/10. still a great game but with little annoying blemishes

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Lego Games. Nearly-consequence-free collect-it-all-a-thon. Simplistic gameplay, drop-in and drop-out local multiplayer, and lots of cool fan pleasing Easter Eggs. I'm a fan of the Traveller's Tales Liscensed Lego Games namely in the references to the source material and the fun treatment they tend to give it and this entry only expanded on the original formula, as I'm sure the series will continue to do in the future. It's great for kids and fun for bored, nerdy, or faint-of-heart people who don't want the stress that comes with certain more intensive platformers and brawlers.

												So, before I start a rant, I would like to state that I love the lego games and will always play them as they are great fun but......From since I was young and getting into games from the beginning, I knew split screen as split screen and I am 100% sure that it wasn't long ago that steam called it that, but, I purchased this game as it stated LOCAL CO-OP, now from when I remember when LOCAL CO-OP came in, it meant that you could play with someone through the same hub, so we had SPLIT SCREEN and LOCAL CO-OP.Why is it now that LOCAL CO-OP means split screen, I fell I have been cheated here on the basis that steam should of specified what it was, BAD JOB STEAM!!!!On another note, this game is brill, if you want to just chill out and play with ease of gameplay and just general fun, buy buy buy!

												Very silly and authentic for fans of the Marvel Universe. The world's greatest supervillains form a cabal to rule the world as a cosmic force makes its way to devour the planet. Only the united forces of the world's greatest heroes, including the Avengers, the X-Men and the rest of the Marvel Universe can stop them! So much fun. content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												This is seriously the best superhero game I've played in a long time!  I'm a 26-year-old male at the time of writing, and it is still very fun for me despite being geared towards a younger audience.  Fun game that is suitable for adults and children alike.  Tons of Marvel heroes and villains to unlock and play as in free mode.  Lots of replayability when going back in free mode looking for extras and such.  This game teaches good lessons about cooperation, and shows that even superheroes can't do everything alone.  I cannot recommend this enough, and I will be buying it for my nieces the very second they are old enough to play it.  I'd buy this game again if I somehow lost access to my copy.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												LEGO has a way of keeping true to the core of the Marvel Universe and still adding their own quirky humor.  I don't know how they do it, they just do it well, and that's what counts.Each of the heroes' (and villians) have powers tailored to them that stay true to their character.  IMO, I think LEGO tends to make better superhero games than some of the serious ones I've seen.  None certainly include the sheer amount of playable chacters.Mission tells a fun story that involves almost all the major mainstays of the Marvel universe.  After finishing the mission, there still the long, and tedious, task of trying to 100% the game.  There's lots to do and this game will kill a lot of time to dedicated achievement unlocker.  Some may find it to be so repetitive that a break will be needed every so often.

content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												This is seriously the best superhero game I've played in a long time!  I'm a 26-year-old male at the time of writing, and it is still very fun for me despite being geared towards a younger audience.  Fun game that is suitable for adults and children alike.  Tons of Marvel heroes and villains to unlock and play as in free mode.  Lots of replayability when going back in free mode looking for extras and such.  This game teaches good lessons about cooperation, and shows that even superheroes can't do everything alone.  I cannot recommend this enough, and I will be buying it for my nieces the very second they are old enough to play it.  I'd buy this game again if I somehow lost access to my copy.

												This game may have some glitches but its still a REALLY fun game. worth the $30. TONS of marvel characters and unlockables, endless replayability with side quests in a lego GTA type open world. So far i have only 1 DLC and its my personal favorite so i reccomend that too. Still even great games have downfalls and this is game has a few irritating ones;1.broken flying controls (i use an xbox controller) the whole flying mechanic is based on a 2 button system and way too complicated2.repetitive gameplay..its a lego game so all you're doing is walking around each mission trying to complete it and blowing everything up along the way for bits.3.weak and pointless bad guys. this isnt that big of a deal because its a gema made for the younger gamers, but for hardcore to casual gamers (like as myself) this is a big one because each level is WAY too easy with boring combat against weak underpowered baddies.as a result i give this a 8/10. still a great game but with little annoying blemishes

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
												Lego Games. Nearly-consequence-free collect-it-all-a-thon. Simplistic gameplay, drop-in and drop-out local multiplayer, and lots of cool fan pleasing Easter Eggs. I'm a fan of the Traveller's Tales Liscensed Lego Games namely in the references to the source material and the fun treatment they tend to give it and this entry only expanded on the original formula, as I'm sure the series will continue to do in the future. It's great for kids and fun for bored, nerdy, or faint-of-heart people who don't want the stress that comes with certain more intensive platformers and brawlers.

												Honestly, when I first bought this game, I thought, "Well, here's yet another Lego game. Gotta keep up my old childhood tradition of playing all the Lego games." But this game was amazing! As you can see, I've clocked over 100 hours, and, in my opinion, the only well thought out reviews are made by thise who have at east invested fifty hours into the game. That said, I didn't see very many cons to the game. The primary one is the grind or all of the characters, but that's a factor throughout all of the Lego games. Pros are as follows:  - Story- HUGE roster- Plenty of side missions-Difficulty enought for older people to play and have fun, but not too hard for younger playersPersonal rating: 9.5/10, becase really no game deserves 10/10 unless it has absolutely no cons.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2015
												Very fun addition to the Lego series of games and definitely a win-win all around. I especially enjoy the fact that they actually attempt to capture each of the character's personalities and replicate them in this game (mostly from the movies they've been in of course) but everyone's dream-take on every character isn't going to be here of course. It's an awesome game for adults to burn some solo-play time on and it will even hold the attention of any parent with a careful eye out for what they put in front of the eyes (and ears) of their kids. There's also a few hidden nuggets (as in all Lego games that have come before) for all those players willing to go the extra mile and actually find each and every last thing in the game. Keep up the great work TT games and I'm sure players (and fans) will happily keep shelling out the bucks...

content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												There are very few games I can define my experience with as being my discrepancy of "fun", but the LEGO Video game franchise has never failed to deliver that to me. Meaning this game is no exception, it has met and well exceeded my expectations from a LEGO game and from a superhero game. It is well balanced but at the same time the characters feel very unique and powerful in their own respect. The game runs great on my PC, I havent had a single texture or hitbox error of the sort you would expect from a low budget PC port, if that is indeed what this is. The physics feel very solid if it were not for the controls being almost frantic, adding super power combo controls to the 4 buttons used in a normal LEGO Video game configuration. The LEGO pieces feel very realistic and have a very plastic weight to them as they would in their actual form, thats not to say that the models that are sold dont feel sold. As for the storyline and the length of the main missions, I believe they are ideal, 15 missions (If im not mistaken) each running about an hour if you really get into exploring the whole level. The story is as good as you would expect from a LEGO game if not a bit better, given that it has character voice actors (Who do lego models a lot of justice for having a voice). All plot lines are well paced and have more than a few catch yet subtle jokes and references, making it a more than enjoyable experience even with the narratives lighthearted tone.In closing, The only thing to say more would be that this is the only review I have every felt necessary enough to post on steam, being a fan of the LEGO Video games and naturally scrutinous of squals, this is easly a 10/10 for the LEGO franchise.Recommend to fans of LEGO, Superheros, and Video games in general.

												Right, so... most people look at this and go 'It's ♥♥♥♥ing LEGO, why the hell should I play it?  It's for kids!'  Well, have you ever considered this tiny, little opinion of, if Steam is correct, 94% of the people who have bought and reviewed it, that the game is just good.  It's silly and fun. Going back for secrets and exploring NYC for others as you unlock more characters with various powers to deal with obstacles.So, yea, it's a LEGO game, it's not serious, but webslinging still felt good (not Spiderman 2 for PS2 good, but we're still hoping someone will once again make a game of that caliber).

Posted: April 21, 2014
												Have you ever been playing Grand Theft Auto and thought: "I wish this was in lego... and I could play as the Incredible Hulk."Yeah good, because it's nothing like that. Good for a rainy day, and once you get through all the missions it IS fun just to run around the open world, but the latter half of the missions reaaaaally drag. Story isn't its strong point, but I don't believe it was ever intended to be. Probably helps to be familiar with the source material (I knew enough to laugh at the jokes the first time they were uttered...)Some cool bits: Guardians of the Galaxy/Ant Man are apparently unlockable! And another* Nick Fury/Pulp Fiction nod (post credits "mission"). And Spider Man in open world is never a bad thing. Ever.Uh yeah. Fun to bash around as Spider Man, Captain America, Hulk for a bit. The other characters are a bit clunky. Get it if it's cheap?

content:
Posted: July 1, 2015
												I've always been a big fan of the Lego game series. Lego Star Wars and Lego Batman were two of many games that I played too much on the PS2 with my brother. Now I'm trying out a 2013 game on the PC, Lego Marvel Super Heroes.The game keeps the same gameplay formula as previous IP's in the series, where you have tons of characters to unlock, a story mode with a lot of collectibles and a free play mode (a big map where you can roam and collect and achieve more). You fight, build, solves puzzles, collect, achieve, race, complete challenges, play different heroes and so on. The story mode is a bit weak and does not offer anything special. The game is pointed towards children and you will get that kids humour a lot :). I would rate the difficulty easy/medium, since some of the challenges are a bit hard. The controls are fair enough on ground level, but I struggle to fly with different heroes. I recommend to play with a controller. You can either play solo, or local split-screen.I bought this game mainly to collect and play different super heroes. The game has a lot of content and so much to achieve. You dont play the game for the story mode, but for the freedom and all the fun you get from the Lego games. I used around 40 hours to collect everything and the game was really fun. There are so many characters to play, vehicles to drive, aircrafts to fly etc. The free play mode gives you a big city to play with. From there you can acess story mode missions, races, get challenges/task from bystanders and do common super hero stuff.   If you like to collect/achieve and are a fan of Lego/Marvel Super Heroes, I strongly recommend this game. I hope you enjoy the game!

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												Great LEGO game? Or greatEST LEGO game?Maybe it's because I'm partial to all things Marvel. Maybe it's the fun voice work. Or, perhaps, the metric buttload of unlockable content, which requires you to go on adventures FAR beyond the story to acquire. Maybe it's the controls, which are not very keyboard friendly, but got me through just fine....no, no it's not that.LEGO Batman 2 has some strengths over this. I thought character interaction during the story mission, and the overall plot, was stronger and more interesting. LEGO Marvel, admittedly, just tore a bunch of stuff out of the various movies and glued it together wherever they could make it sort of fit. Buuuuuuuut on the bright side, that still ended up being awesome.I know we're all probably sick of LEGO games by now, but LEGO Indiana Jones and Pirates of the Caribbean are behind us...so we no longer have to worry so much about them definitely being terrible and worth skipping. We can say, with reasonable certainty, that whatever Traveller's Tales pumps out next for an instant cash in will be playable, illicit a bunch of smiles, and perhaps drop upon us a crippling addiction to unlockable characters.

number of helpful: 4 of 10 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												Having just played Lego Batman 2 and 3 consecutively, this was a disappointment. It just seemed like a quick cash-in. Getting 100% studs, while I usually dont care about getting them, was so easy that not even going out of your way to get them results in 100% studs near the halfway point in every level. They didnt even bother to make it any kind of challenge. Being forced to use control stations around the world to change characters until you've completeled the story was very annoying too. That just seemed like a way to pad game length even further. The engine didnt seem to be very optimized either on PC. For such a simple game the fps would almost drag to a halt in certain non-intensive areas. While I appreciate that the story didnt follow any of the movies (I find those Lego games to be boring as ive already seen the movies) this still felt lame to me and after seeing recent Lego Marvel's Avengers gameplay it seems that will be a proper Lego Marvel game, but sadly its going to follow the Avenger movies. UGH, booooooooooring.Not worth full price, but its something to play, at a discount, if you're a devout Lego game buyer  :|

												Game was awesome. It was great until I reached up to the 15th and final level where we fight Galactus. Something happened. A bug happened And I can't smash a couple of bricks that I have to smash. I tried like 6-7 times. Resetted the level, resetted the game, resetted the computer. But no. It didn't work. And It just ruined my gameplay. Now I cannot complete the game. I cannot play with the Symbiote Spider-Man that I have paid extra money for. I can't refund the game because I have over 2 hours of gameplay. Guess what? I lost my money. And the worst part is that they will NOT fix this bug since the game is 2 years old. An awesome game, became the most annoying game ever. Please consider the bugs before you buy this game and DON'T do what I did, Don't pay the full price for this. Wait for a sale and than buy it if you want.

												This is one of the best Lego games I've played.Pretty wide selection of character/abilities(I know every Lego game does this. It just seems to be a little more so in this case. This entry into the Lego series is virtually bug free.(1 or 2 minor issuse, nothing game breaking or overtly annoying.No suicide inducing jump sections(I'm glaring at you Lego LotR). This would have been a great one to play with a buddy.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												I wish I could recommend this game. I really do. In terms of the positives, the gameplay is fun, although simple. There is a robust cast of characters from the Marvel universe, each with their own unique abilities and many of which that have multiple costumes and so forth. There are some puzzle areas where characters must work together to overcome an obstacle. There are plenty of collectibles to keep you playing and keep you coming back.Now for the reasons I cannot recommend this game. I cannot tell you the number of times I ran into gamebreaking bugs. There were so so many and all of varying types. In some areas where an event is supposed to trigger, it simply doesn't and you can no longer progress, forcing you to restart from your last save point or the beginning of the mission. Other times, your character can end up in an infinite death loop, again making it impossible to progress. Then there are times when you switch to controlling one of your other characters who the A.I. managed to trap behind a ladder. Try killing him and he respawns in the same place, right behind that ladder, still stuck. Again, this makes it impossible to progress. Add to this the occasional crash and there you have it. The game becomes too damn frustrating to want to play anymore. And this isn't a once-time or occasional thing. These game-breaking bugs occur REGULARLY. When I looked some of these bugs up, I found guides to the game that specifically had to warn you about these bugs and actively show you how to avoid them as part of the game guide. It's like there was absolutely no QA testing on this game. The Lego franchise games are usually terrific, but this one was a terrible misstep in the series, which is unfortunate because it had the potential to be one of my favorites considering the universe in which it is set. Do not play this game unless you have the patience of a saint.

This is par for the course in LEGO games and being that this is D3D9 it is simple to set this up (on NVIDIA GPUs).

number of helpful: 3 of 10 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27
												It's boring. It's incredibly boring.This is generally true of all Lego games. You run from level to level mashing the attack button constantly to destroy the environment and the enemies that pose absolutely no threat whatsoever. Scattered throughout the levels are various gates that can only be bypassed with certain abilities. Most people would call these "puzzles," but I don't think it qualifies as a puzzle when you run up to it and the game tells you exactly what you need to do. It's just a hoop thrown out by the developers to make players jump through it before they can move on to the next section and continue destroying everything in sight to collect studs. After doing this for what feels like seven eternities back to back, there will be a boss fight where the boss spends 99% of the fight utterly invulnerable to your attacks until a certain amount of time has passed or until you've killed enough of the enemies that spawn to remind you how terrible the combat is. Want to master the combat? Press the attack button. That's all there is to it. This is the last time I'm going to try to get into one of these games. Since the original trilogy's Star Wars game on PS2, I've been trying, and I'd guess that I've played at least seven different Lego games, including Dimensions, which my sister poured nearly $700 into. They are all exactly the same: run around, smash everything, collect studs, press the attack button until enemies are dead, use the character the game tells you to use to solve one of its "puzzles," and then move on to the next area to repeat. It's almost like a psychological experiment to determine the bare amount of "gameplay" people can put up with, or an experiment to determine how many times the same exact game can be re-released with different character sets. This game sucks, and Telltale needs to stop re-releasing it. I'm ashamed of myself for buying it, because I knew exactly what I would find--the same thing found in literally every other Lego video game.So the experiment is clearly a success. Now please, Telltale Games, call it off.

number of helpful: 0 of 4 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19
												Just so boring…Story:A bunch of bad guys escaped. Use the good guys to defeat them. And the bad guys at one point to defeat Galactus and Loki. It’s a simple plot but it just goes almost nowhere. In the beginning, it's established that you need to go after the cosmic bricks. And you spend almost every single ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ level doing that. It seems like the plot got off the ground for 5 seconds, plateaued and fell back at the end. It has no interesting story and is just boring really.There are a fair amount of characters to play through in the main story although you don’t unlock the villains until the end. Each hero is just a 1D mock of themselves. Captain America loves America, Iron Man is rich and shows off, Hulk is strong. They try to play it up for laughs but it’s just not that funny. In other games, at least there was slapstick or visual humor. Here, there’s visual humor in the beginning and ending cutscenes and that's it. It’s just boring and uninteresting. Gameplay:It’s a lego game. You hit bricks, collect studs, fight, and build. It’s a simple concept and almost unchanged. The attention is back on using the abilities of the superheroes which makes sense but you can only have 4 at a time which I found kinda boring. However, this makes sense when you realize that most of the characters are actually the same. Iron man and Human torch can fire heat beams to destroy gold bricks. Hulk and The Thing are strong and can pick up heavy stuff. Thor and Storm use lighting (yes Thor can fly but I never used it) to open switches. When you consider that, it narrows the heroes down a lot and you end up with like 4 or 5 abilities spread through all of them. This is a problem considering the levels are just absolutely enormous so you end up repeating so much♥♥♥♥♥♥over and over again but with pallet swapped characters. Plus, the fighting is so simple that you can’t fall back on it.There are hub worlds and literally an open city where you can have races and collect stuff with mini quests but I didn’t care because again, all boring and you only do it for completion. Now the most annoying thing in the entire game: THE ♥♥♥♥ING FLYING CONTROLS. Jesus ♥♥♥♥ing christ these are horrible. On a keyboard, you press “w” to go forward and “J,K” to rise and fall but press them for too long and characters just freak the ♥♥♥♥ out and it’s just horrible. Plus, most of the time, the level doesn’t even require you to fly. So what's the point? Maybe to get around the hub world faster but you don’t always have a flying character and your GPS doesn’t work while flying. GREATGraphics/Performance: (with a 970, 4790K, 16GB of RAM, SSD)I wish I could skip cutscenes. Like the minute long beginning that I’ve watched multiple times. And it crashed a couple of times. The game looks fine but stutters a lot when loading a new area or expanding out and it’s jarring. Also, some animations look horrible. Mister Fantastic stretching is the jankiest♥♥♥♥♥♥when dealing with a lego.Final Thoughts:This is the first time I’ve just been bored with a lego game. Most of the other games have similar problems to the ones above but they have something else that makes it worth it. HP had slapstick and the story. LOTR had the story (and a LOT of the annoyances). The lego movie game had interesting segments, enemies, and settings (while having the personality and padding issues). This game is just flat out boring and my I had to motivate myself to finish it. That’s always a bad sign.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												I had high hopes for this game. I really did. I mean, I love lego games, and I love Marvel comics (even if I think that DC is better). How could it go wrong? It was like a match made in heaven! Unfortunately, it didn't turn out to be one.First off, it isn't really a bad game, it can even be considered as a pretty decent one. But for me, It was a massive disappointment.I'll start with the pros: +The hughe cast of character. There is a LOT of character, and that is great.+The open world sections are pretty fun, it can be really amusing to run around New York as one of your favorite characters.+The levels are pretty well made, forcing you to play with various characters and using their abilities to reach the end, like in any lego videogame. I know a lot of people don't like this mechanic, but I don't mind it.And the cons:-I hate comic books movies. I really do. And why I really hate marvel movies, is because they now leave their mark in comics. For exemple, Hulk is now stupid again, we have the "Nick Fury jr" and Coulson bullcrap, and Iron Man, one of Marvel's worst and most hateable character (at least, in my opinion), is now the big figure of Marvel. And the game is fully influenced by the movies, with Iron Man everywhere (Urgh), Coulson and many more things that are just here to please people who only watch the movies.Ho and poor Dr.Aldrich Killian and Mandarin. Iron Man 3♥♥♥♥♥♥♥you and this game continues.-There is a really poor use of characters. A lot of great characters are here, but they are just not the characters that I grew up to love. Their personnality is either altered, or thrown in a wash machine. They are often used in a really poor way. I get it, most of it is used for the humor and all and all, but sorry, Doctor Octopus cleaning up Daily Bugle office? really-Many characters are here. But you need mondey to buy them. And they aren't cheap. At all. So be prepare to do a lot of grinding if you want them all. I don't mind grinding, but for this game, it was just not worth it.-The music is annoying as hell. More than once, I cut the sound. However the one when you jump of the Hellcarier is actually pretty good.-Boss battles are repetitive as ♥♥♥♥.-The final level... I won't say anything. Just knowing that it exists is enough.-Also if like me, you don't have a controller, you may find the control a little bit unfriendly. The game wasn't made for a keyboard and you can see it really quickly.Conclusion: I excpected a lot from this game, maybe too much. I didn't like how the characters I like were treated and the fact that the Marvel movies now spread their influence everywhere just makes me furious. I wanted to love this game, and even though it played ok, in the end, it was a massive disappointment.

												IF YOU USE A PS3/PS4 CONTROLLER, DO NOT BUY. Controller support is VERY broken, even a year and a half after release. There is a currently unfixable bug that forces co-op when using a PS3/PS4 controller, but only player 1 can drop out and there's no way to assign the controller to a character without triggering the co-op mode. If you use a 360 controller, there is a fix but it isn't particularly intuitive. Devs do not respond to the issue and have not made any acknowledgement of the problem.

number of helpful: 3 of 11 people (27%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Wonderful, just wonderful.  Traveler's Tales released yet another LEGO game, what a bore.  Hmm? What's this?  It's based on Marvel Comics?  Hmmm...then this game might have a chance. Unfortunately, it doesn't. If you have played (most of) the previous LEGO games made by Traveler's Tales, you'll see what I mean.  Every single LEGO game that comes out is the same thing: Break stuff, build stuff, get studs, buy stuff with studs, use specific characters to unlock secret stuff, etc. and the series just gets crappier and crappier. Nothing really changes in the LEGO games, but hey, at least they talk in this one.  The gameplay in LEGO games never change, sure this game is one of the first open-world hub LEGO games, but that doesn't change its gameplay. The puzzles and things you do are still the same silly, unoriginal, ridiculous things  that actually make it feel like LEGO, but not the thing that's in LEGO form, not for one moment in these games can those puzzles and stuff you do be serious and original.  A lot of people say the controls are crappy in this game, but I kind of grew up with PC gaming so I am used to any PC controls no matter how bad.  Yes, the flying and vehicle controls are kind of weird and eventually get annoying, but I don't really care and it doesn't bother me anymore.  By the way, who gives a flying rats crappy behind about mouse control?!  Seriously, it's a LEGO game, they never have mouse control, deal with it you freakin' idiots!The story is original, I'll give it that, but terrible. The humor is weak and there's too much of it. And some of the story doesn't even make any sense, for instance, Doctor Octopus and Agent Coulson cleaning up the Daily Bugle, seriously?  I know this game's audience was heavily targeted at children, but they could've been a bit more serious with this game. Come on, it's Marvel, treat it with respect you loony-toony game developers. And what the heck is Howard the Duck doing in this game?  Better yet, what the heck is Howard the Duck doing in Marvel in the first place?!Now I want to go on record and say that I LOVE the Marvel films, but this game just makes a mockery of all of it. They even left out some key Marvel characters: Quick Silver, Ultron, Scarlet Witch, Vision, and other important characters.Oh wait, you want to get %100? Oh hoh hoh hoh hoh hoooooh! These games are RELENTLESS when it comes to secret content. It will take you MONTHS to unlock every single little damn thing in this game. I only own ONE LEGO game where I got %100, ONE. Trust me, don't waste your time unlocking all that crap, it's just not worth it. I would rather watch Disney's Frozen a thousand times so I can play the whole damn movie in my head while having Let it Go stuck in my head in the process than get %100 in LEGO Marvel Super Heroes.This game is crap. Don't you DARE buy this game, because if you do, you'll be giving Traveler's Tales money and giving them another reason to create another one of these LEGO-shaped garbage cans. If you're a kid, this game will probably be the best thing that's ever happened to you. If you're an adult, not so much.3.8/10 Seriously, don't bother with this game. If I were you, I'd instead wait for Rovio to come up with an Angry Birds Marvel Super Heroes and buy it immediatley. Yeah, I'm pretty sure Marvel in Angry Birds would probably be a whole lot better than this stupid game, trust me.

												LEGO MARVEL Super Heroes is my first venture into a lego game and while I didn't hate it, I didn't love it either. There is a first for everything and I'm glad I tried.The game is very linear with 15 levels and while at times I got stuck, it always end up being some easy task which I didn't think of, or some lego structure I didn't smash through. The boss fights at the end of every level are extremely easy and repetitive though. To be honest, I enjoyed the puzzles more.I would not recommend this game, with the pushing factor that if anyone were to read this review, it would be someone on my friend list, and most of them wouldn't enjoy it either. However, it would be a different story if you are getting it for your children. It could provide suitable entertainment with mild stimulation and it might be worth purchasing the game when it goes on sale again.6/10

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												WILL NOT BUY!I played this game through a friends shared library on Steam (a fantastic system that we have so far had no problems with AT ALL)After completing quite a large portion of the game, and succesfully beginning and ending multiple game sessions, I booted the game and to my surprise it asked to confirm installation. I did so, and when the game booted, the option to continue my game was available, however, once I clicked it, I was told no save data could be found.Perplexed, I began the computer-wide search for said files, (I do know what I'm doing) without success. I then proceeded to search the crap out of forums, community hubs and other sources for a solution or suggestion. After much digging and searching, I discovered where my saves SHOULD have been, but were not. No trace. Not even the parent folder.I checked my 9 day old system back-up, only to discover that the file structure was in place, and the saves (albeit from a much earlier session) were there.This does not make me happy, can you see why? Something, somewhere, has decided it had the authorization to delete files from MY computer without my knowledge or say so. It is a bug in the programming, not windows, not steam, and certainly not user error.It hasn't been widely reported, but I'm not the only person this has happened to, and from all I can find, it's not at a certain point in the game, or a certain percentage level of completion, but it has deleted both the saves and the parent folder of the saves on other peoples systems.NEVER, have I had a problem with any LEGO game in the past, but this made me furious. To the degree that I will not purchase this game, ever. I have deleted the shared copy and I willl never play it again, and I will discourage all my friends from supporting it. This is sloppy, the bug hasn't been addressed and considering the money behind the game and the name it's representing, I expect far better.Well done on ruining what could have been another fantastic experience.

number of helpful: 0 of 5 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												If you like the Lego gamescape you'll like this title.  I highly recommend getting a game controller for the PC version as the keyboard setup is cumbersome to say the least.  And there is NO advantage in buying thise title if you own the console version!At first I was happy to see "Local COOP", as in other games (not Lego) Local COOP had usually meant LAN-locked connectivity.  However, disappointment reigned as my son and I discovered "Local COOP" really means, shared keyboard or multiple game controllers used on ONE computer.Had high hopes we could play drop-in-style as a family or with friends using either our laptops or desktops wherever we were comfortable at home or away:(  So, I'm rating this a thumbs down on that one hangup as otherwise I'd have saved the cost of buying multiple copies and just stayed with the console version.

I seriously spent a lot of time trying to figure out a cool application of my hero's power to the first level that I forgot that the only method I was allowed to use was to walk up to the place I was supposed to, tap a button, switch characters, tap another button, and hope while I'm executing this my teammate's AI will be competent enough to cover me from the droves of infinitely spawning enemies trying to hinder my endeavor. It was frustrating and unrewarding to complete every task in the game so far, and the abundance of possible solutions to problems entailed by even the 3 characters I was allowed to briefly play as was neglected for unchallenging and unfun 'slow time events'.

content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
												Nice clean graphics, good storyline however very difficult and cumbersome PC controls.  All the characters from the Marvel universe are recognisable complete with amusing one-liners.  Its a very lazy console port that hasnt really been ported well at all.  The mouse has no function and I often found that I was stuck without the keys working as the should or I couldnt work out what key should be pressed.  The view is also very annoying as you cant spin it around so only have the single viewpoint and some things get obscured because of this.  If you really want to play this game then you will need a PC controller.  I bought one and the game became so much better.   It gets a non-recommendation because of the unwieldy PC controls that make the game more or less unplayable without an XBox controller.  This is my first Lego game purchase and it will be the last.

												Horrible.Probably could be an incredibly fun game, but after countless reinstall and even a reformat of the computer... this game freezes for no reason at all. content:
Posted: September 21, 2014
												I enjoyed the early LEGO titles and played them to completion, but their games have been going steadily downhill. Including voice acting took away a lot of the cool creative aspects of their games. This one fails on sheer mechanics. Iron Man's explosives would target, but not blow up the items they were supposed to. Spider Man would hook on to a handle but the spastic mechanism (press K repeatedly until the progress bar fills) wouldn't work. Similarly the Hulk would let go in the middle of a progress bar. This game may work on a different platform, but I couldn't finish the first segment do to shoddy implementation.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												If you've ever wanted to play through some of DC's most classic lineup of superheroes and supervillains, this is the game that you've been waiting for your entire life.The gameplay is fairly standard and similar to other LEGO games, in that you run around mashing the attack button on any object you can see in order to collect studs, in one of the games most striking allegorical moments about the occupation of Palestine and the wars that followed.The story is as follows: When Ego the Living Planet is awakened by the energies of Randy Savage's death, several classic villains such as Anti-Monitor, Time Trapper, and Superboy Prime are sent to Earth to destroy it. However, in an ironic twist, the entire cast of Marvel Zombies has ravaged the planet, causing the supervillains to fight for the rights of mankind. Are the bad guys bad enough dudes to save the world from the once-heroes?There's free roam at the end but it sucks if you don't have a character that can fly, correctly mirroring issues of gender inequality and violations of LGBTQQAA2SPUBBQ members around the world, and I applaud Capcom Studios for looking past their collective cis privledge in order to present a game as emotionally moving as Gone Home by Anita Sarkeesian.Who is bad? Who is good? This and more you'll find in the hood. Play as Big Bird, Cool Spot, and the Six Flags guy in order to bring peace once more.0/10 no sherk

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												The game is way too easy. In just under an hour you will easily have over 100-200 extra lives. Also in order to play the hero you want, you have to follow a linear storyline unlocking each character one-by-one which may take a really long time for some of the heroes lower on the list.EDIT: I notice that many people disagree with my review but I would like to point out that it is not because I am wrong, but because I have left out some other key detail about this game -- as in, "despite all of that it is still a good game". Sure, you might argue that dying and seamlessly respawning on the same screen for a whopping 1,000 out of your millions-of-credits denies you the upgrades you need to buy with those, when the game is already ridiculously easy. I could also see how you might argue that this game is perfect for younger audiences when, actually, you would just rather not play it yourself. This game does not teach eye-hand-coordination or problem-solving skills and being a "Press Y when it tells you to press Y" game I would not recommend it to anyone, feel free to comment, thanks.

content:
Posted: April 15
												I played the first 3 or 4 levels and quickly realized this is basically an interactive movie.  It's just a long series of super simplistic puzzles that you don't figure out so much as you just follow the on screen instructions.  You press B when it says to.  Press X when it says to.  Follow the color queues to know which character to use.  And after every 10 second task you get to watch some more animated events/cutscenes.  Great game for young children.  Nothing here for adults.

number of helpful: 6 of 24 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Being a big fan of the Lego games, especially after the epic advenure the Lord of the Rings one was, I was super psyched to see my super heroes in a game.Straight to the point, keeping in mind I'm only an hour or two into it, it's been a major let down. The voice acting could have been much better. The voices chosen for each weren't really well picked and don't really fit some of the characters at all. The characters that are portrayed in the newer movies all have that voice people are used to. Lego Lord of the Rings brought all the original cast to re-voice the characters. They should have done the same for this as well seeing as they more than likey would have had the money.The gameplay has been pretty spot on as you would have hoped. Flying around and shooting energy balls with Iron Man, Hulk Smashing your foes with the Hulk, shooting webs with Spiderman are all a blast. Spiderman's web slinging could have been more interactive ( I sitll think the Spiderman 3 game has the best web slinging controls ever) but it IS a kid's game so, no points docked there.What reaaallly gets me the most, is the "story". It just doesn't have that Marvel-esque touch that the comics and cartoons had. The story just feels broken and uninteresting. Nothing to get you hyped about playing anyone, just, oh here's some chaos happening, have these 3 particular heroes and deal with it. Another issue, for me personally is I hate Fantastic 4, they're boring, uncreative and just irritating and too much of a portion of the game in the beginning has to deal with them, again that's a personal issue.The biggest irritation, is in all the lego games you had to destroy structures to release blocks to build something to aid you. They always had that "tell" that you could just look around and spot it and say "ya..I bet I have to break that thing". Here, everything blends in too well, everything looks normal. You will spend more time breaking everything in an area to reveal the blocks to build something than you do spending playing the game for the story. It's almost like they're forcing the "break everything" on you.Is it a good game? Probably my least favorite of all of them, which hurts to say because I love Marvel comics. Is it worth the price tag even on sale? Hell no. If it was 10 bucks maybe. At it's current price and Thanksgiving sale, I'd be much happier buying a second copy of Lego Lord of the Rings.

												The first, and last lego game I'm buying for the PC. The usual of what you'd expect from a lego game. Riddled with horrific bugs and the usual "lego game concept". number of helpful: 3 of 19 people (16%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												The writing is very very bad.  Constant puns - and horrible ones.  It is clear they were trying for a tone similar to Joss Whedon's Avengers, but decided against hiring a good writer.  The level design is bland, and at times the obstacles are mind-boggling.  Characters that can fly have to blow up 6 foot obstacles before they can proceed through the level?  Lots of invisibile walls, which in my mind always always equates to poor game design and inexperienced developers.  With Marvel behind this, you'd think they would have invested a couple dollars hiring a legitimate development team, one that could come up with a better level design than the weak offerings within.  I bought the game for the setting, and the characters, but it is really a poor offering and disappoints beyond words.  Poor form, LEGO and Marvel.  P.S.  Yes, I understand it was targeted for kids, but when we look at games like Disney Infinity and Skylanders, there's a lot more room for improvement.

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												This game is freaking awesome. I started playing the LEGO games on PS2 starting with Star Wars. Everything that game embodies is still in this one. The cool overworld, the incredibly large character selection, the puzzling... puzzles, and etc. Marvel is also my favorite franchise producers, from Spiderman to Ironman to Hulk and the X-men, they're all in this game. The overworld is probably my favorite part because it's almost like LEGO GTA. You can hijack civilian cars and drive them around into light posts and mailboxes, running over civilians (they just fall over), flying jet planes, and finding secrets. You can change into characters you unlocked at any time in the overworld too. I don't understand why I haven't played this game sooner. Something that may throw some people off though, is that this game is voice acted. Most LEGO games I've played make the characters do interpretive movements to let the player know what's happening. Not this one.

												Warning for potential buyers: This game requires a controller or gamepad. The keyboard controls are absolutely unacceptably atrocious. They want your right hand to be on HJKL and also hit the arrow keys. That will never happen. Luckily, I had a 360 PC controller, plugged it in, the game automatically recognized it and switched to controller mode, and the controls work beautifully. Play it with a controller!Aside from the initial shock at how immensely bad the keyboard controls were, this game is really fun. If you like LEGO anything, you'll probably like LEGO Marvel. You can play as a vast array of different heroes and even villains, and beat up bad guys. The game really opens up as you progress, allowing free-roam of New York City after a certain point. It plays a lot like other free-roam games, you have a map with objectives and you can do side-stuff along the way, collecting and unlocking as you go. The main plot is the only true drawback for me. It's definitely there, but each mission feels disjointed. There's so much that you have to skip because you haven't unlocked a character yet. I spend more time trying to figure out if a shiny unbreakable object is something I can activate than progressing. Fortunately there are a lot of details from Marvel canon and beyond that the development team added to make even the dull parts amusing. And as always, the gameplay is top notch. LEGO games all feel the same and I like that about them, but they went above and beyond in LEGO Marvel Super Heroes to make each hero play differently. I'm not halfway through the game yet and I've already played as probably 15 different heroes, each with a unique style and skillset. It's just downright fun.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												Alright - I'll admit, this game isn't as hard as many games out there. I mean, honestly, I've put half as much time into this as I have Deus Ex: Human Revolution, and I still haven't beaten the story yet in the latter.However, I can tell you for a fact that it is a FUN game. It has surprisingly high-quality voice acting, as well as an original storyline combining pretty much every important Marvel character in history. And a duck. We don't talk about the duck. While it  can take a bit of practice to get the hang of the keyboard targeting programs, it makes up for that with the seeking quality of projectiles, and there is a wide variety of different heroes, villains, and Deadpool you can use to figure out different situations and help different people.Oh, and don't forget - DEADPOOL. Oh god. He's hilarious. The first time I noticed him, I was just fighting Doc Ock in Times Square, and then I looked up. And then I was like 'Oh, look, there's Deadpool in a helicopter videotaping the whole thing - wait what?' He just pops up in the most random of places, and has this innate ability to be hilarious. He's also the narrator in bonus levels, which gets extra hilarity thrown in.But yea. I highly suggest you buy this game.

												I was initially disappointed after purchasing two copies of Lego Marvel with the intention of both my husband and I playing together via Steam - co-op is only available via split screen couch co-op which is rather difficult with a keyboard only based game.  I'm sure it's easy enough to set up a controller for use with the game but we both felt that LAN and Online co-op was something the game was severely lacking.With that said, I have throughly enjoyed playing the game solo so far. Each playable character has their own feel and set of special powers and although the majority of the game is smashing up lego bricks and collecting the coins it's therapeutic. In addition some of the puzzles are more challenging than previous Lego games. I look forward to putting more hours into this game and unlocking all the extra characters.

												In my opinion this is by far the best Lego game. If you've never played a Lego game before you should know that these games are very lighthearted; childish even. But they're great fun for all ages. You should be a Marvel fan to appreciate everything this game has to offer, and it does have a lot to offer. There's a ridiculous number of Marvel characters, all of whom can be played as. The story is surprisingly good. The length of some sequences can be tiresome, which could have been avoided if the story perspective changed to another superhero for a bit to break the monotony. Definitely play with a gamepad and not a mouse and keyboard.

												This is the first lego game I tried, and I found it clever and entertaining at first, but quickly became repetitous. content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												Before I begin this review, I must point out this caveat to you. There are approximately three things in this world that I love above all other things, the first is Lego. I am a Lego collector (specifically super hero Lego at that). The second is comic books and super heroes. Ever since I've been able to use my eyes and hands in unison I've loved the world of super heroes, specifically Marvel. The third is video games.So this game is ticking all three boxes for me. And it is simply brilliant. The main story is a lot of fun, but in reality feels like the prologue to the rest of the game, a quest to collect the myriad different characters (there are some amazing and obscure characters to collect) and complete side missions etc. Literally hours of fun. It also is genuinely funny. I actually found myself laughing out loud on several occasions. In a room. On my own. Laughing. Which is especially amazing as I'm currently being treated for depression. So thanks Lego Marvel Super Heroes. You've not only been a welcome distraction, but have given me some drive and purpose and genuinely had me feeling happy when I've felt anything but.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												This game is awesome. The guys at lego really brought their A game to this title. It is surprisingly well rendered, the characters are true to their marvel comics origins, something that several of the movies have failed at (looking at you "X-men" movies). The humor is apropriate for the subject matter. And the cast is Ginormous, from the black panther to the punisher, to Dr strange, all of the major players are here. Though i was hoping for some of the more obscure figures like cloak and dagger to be here, if they are i'll revise this when i find them. Anyway, i whole heartedly recommend this to any fan of Lego or Marvel or games in general. I enjoy this game and my kids enjoy it too. Oh, almost forgot, i love the way that split screen play behaves in this game, starting with the standard vertical divide during exploration in manhattan, during campaign play the divide is dynamic from vertical to diagonals and fusing when possible, an innovation i hope to see much more wide spread.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												This was probably one of my favorite LEGO games, not necessarily because of the source material because I was never a Marvel fanatic, but I was after playing this.  There are 15 missions that last 20-30 minutes, they're the standard lego puzzles that require certain abilities to get past.  The story is a standard superheroes vs. villains story but it manages to expand to as many parts of the Marvel Universe so it no 2 levels feel the same.  When not in a mission there is a big open world Manhatten with plenty of side missions and tasks to keep you occupied for hours.  Some of the most fun I have is jumping into New York from the hellicarrier, and boy did they knock the music out of the park.Lastly the best part is all the different characters you can play.  Beyond the standard Avengers, X-men, Spiderman, and Fantastic Four characters their are dozens of others some even more obscure.  You can run around as a LEGO Blade or Punisher, and of course there is Deadpool who pretty much narrates all the non main story parts.  Riding around as Captain Britain in the britmobile was funny as well.  The two DLCs add more characters from the new movies, no updated Falcon though :( .  If you like LEGO games or Marvel this game is definately a must.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												An outstanding Lego game. It has nice graphics and a good, long storyline. I have played other lego games before and have always liked them, but i can say this is the best one so far. There are a lot of characters with their own animations and different kind of actions. You can play many of Marvel's superheroes and villains. The developers have done a good job in making lego objects more on the foreground, as this is what i missed in other lego games. It has given me much more of that lego feeling. There is much interaction with the open world, New York, and levels are well-designed. Compared to other lego games it is a bit harder to play, but not in a way that it isn't fun anymore. It has nice cutscenes, containing complex lego structures. I would highly recommend this to others who like lego games, as it certainly is worth the price.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												A very accurate representation of a Marvel unieverse in the form of Lego, if you enjoyed the comics and movies for all these characters then you will love this game, there are classic references to the new Marvel movies and classic comic books. The game expands into characters never seen on screen before, play as characters like Iron man, Thor and other Marvel classics. But also expect characters like the Guardians of the galaxy, even Ant man and Squirrel girl! Don't expect too much variation in character powers though, once you get probably half way through the game you've pretty much seen all powers, however do not let this comment dishearten you! There is plenty of content in this game and I've definitely spent a lot of time on this game , both in local co-operative and single player, the controls are unsturdy as they are mainly built for controller, so if you have a controller I definitely recommend using it as I found it easier to use a controller. I rate this game 8/10, fantastic dialogue and writing, gameplay and action. Also Clark Gregg voices Coulson! I guess he is the definitive Coulson!

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												A fairly impressive game that will engage people of all ages.  A huge open world, tons of unlockable characters and LEGO's quirky humor make this game a rewarding play.  That being said there are some game-breaking bugs specifically in the story-driven missions.  Sometimes the puzzles are less intuitive than may be expected, leaving the player searching for a fair amount of time to find the solution.  Even taking these issues into consideration this game is a fun, super hero/villain driven massive open world surprise that I wholeheartedly recommend.

												This game was very fun but had alot of downfalls such as the end boss being very boring and some of the playable charactors powers were not what they are like in the comics , movies and T.V shows. On the other hand it is really fun to play with a friend and the gameplay is strangly addictalbe even though it seems to be quite boring. There are alot of playable charactors nearly all of them are unique alhtough some of the ones you get at the end of the game seem to have simuler abilities from the starter charactors. All around this game has fun mechanics, great with friends and so many charactors you can play as. There may be alot youo can re-play this gam for like all the collectables but it is deffinityly not fun doing this game on your own a second time   unless you have a friend. Over all this game is quite good with a few paticular things it could improve on I would give it a 7/10

Posted: July 4, 2014
												Extremely fun game with a lot of comical references to everything in the marvel universe. Game feels like it can get repetitive at times, and most puzzles are easily solved as long as you have the right super powers, but the open world of new york, the huge character cast, and the ability to explore some of the most well-known locations in the marvel universe makes this game definitly worth playing. Many have wanted an open world marvel game for years, and while I bet this wasn't what they were expecting, it's well worth the experience.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												10/10When I saw that Webm of Iron Man jumping off of the helicarrier and swooping into New York City, I was sold.  This game really gives you the full Marvel experience.  Play as some of your favorite Marvel characters like Absorption Man, Polaris, Wizard, um, Mastermind, I guess and, uh, Howard the Duck.  If a full-grown man-child can enjoy this game made for children, then so can you.Pros:- Flying is great- Absorption ManCons:- No Absorption Man-centric storyline.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												My son and I have played this game for countless hours.  It is by far, the best Lego game to date.  They actualy voiced the characters this time.  And its not pre recorded audio from a movie either.  The puzzels in the game were easy enough for my 5 year old to figure out, but on occasion needed help.  The humor from the previous lego games is there too.  There is an incredible amount of characters to unlock.  The ability for flying characters to go from the ground, fly around, and go into the sky up to the helicarrier is cool too.  They built an entire city to explore and do things in.  Many actual levels of pre scripted game play is avaible too.  I highly recomend it for a 5 year old and up.  Even as an adult I really enjoyed the game.  If i had more than two thumbs, they would all be up!  My setup is a 4 year old pc with a geforce 460.  Its an older video card and it handles the game on all the highest settings perfectly.  I have a wireless Microsoft controller (is identical to the 360) that the hub it come with allows 4 controllers to connect to.  I use an extra xbox 360 controller to play with it.  From there, I have an HDMI cable running to my home theater system to play the game on a big tv.

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												I purchased this game for my 3yr old nephew and for myself of course, to get down on. There aren't to many local co-op games suitable for toddlers. Sonic, Renegade Ops, Pac-Man, Galaga, Mario's and this one. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 29, 2015
												Let me preface this by saying that I am a HUGE fan of the LEGO games. I've played at least 6 and finished them to 100% completion. But this one...I didn't. I beat all the levels, but never felt compelled to keep playing or find all of the hidden items in each level. I like Marvel, I like the Cinematic Universe, but maybe it's the fact that it's a brand new story rather than a retelling of an already familiar one that was getting me down. Basically, the premise is this: your favorite Marvel superheroes together (and villains teaming up), something that the movies could never do with different studios owning the rights to various franchises. The story's not bad, and it has a good mix of humor (they got Tony Stark down, even without RDJ voicing), and it's really fun to see the interactions between supers that you normally don't get to see. The banter between them is fantastic. But as for gameplay? There's nothing groundbreaking with this one, same old same old. The levels are LONG, and even though they have a save feature so you can quit in the middle of the level, it's few and far between, and ithe option will disappear if you activate the save point then don't save. So, yeah, had to redo a few levels because of glitches because I wasn't using the save points and there's no autosave in the middle of a level. There was also another game-breaking glitch where one of the bosses gets stuck in one corner that happened to me TWICE that required restart of the level from the beginning. Annoying.So, if you REALLY love the LEGO games or REALLY love Marvel, you will probably still enjoy it. Otherwise...meh. Go play LEGO Harry Potter or LEGO Star Wars instead, honestly.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												Lego games have been getting increasingly more creative and amazing over the years. Games like Lego Star Wars 1, though still amazing, do not compare graphically and combat-wise, with some of these newer games. Lego Marvel Super Heroes is an excellent bland of adventure, action, and open word gaming. It is perfect for kids, though older people may have a hard time remaining pacified with this game. The streets of New York provide an excellent portion of this games open world features, with the ability to travel to islands and different locations all over the place. The character variety is amazing. I believe that Lego Lord of the Rings is the only other Lego game with the same minifigure variety as this game. Lego Marvel Super Heroes exceeds Lego LOTR with the variety of characters powers and abilities. The addition of a character customization station pretty much completes this game. In it (the customizer) you can combine different heroes body parts to give your creation a combination of certain heroes' powers. My younger siblings have made a hybrid spider-man/captain America. It's probably the game's best feature. Lego Marvel Super Heroes is definitely something kids will enjoy. I myself do not play it all that much, but my little sibs do, and they love it. 10/10 another great Lego game!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 14, 2015
												Lego Marvel Super Heroes has the same awesome qwerky style that all Lego games possess which makes the game fun and enjoyable. This feels more of a developed Lego game as characters have a wide range of abilities and navigating through the levels requires work from every character. However, there are some problems. First, you can clearly see this is designed with controller in mind. You still can’t bind keys with the mouse which is ridiculous. Why can't I attack with left click just like all games do? I also think they made filling the stud meter to 100% way too easy. You used to have to destroy everything, pick up almost every stud to fill it, and that's how it should be. But I’m filling it up most of the time just playing the level normally, not even having to search for purple studs or anything. On the other hand, they made finding the minikits too difficult in my opinion. Anways, this game is still really, really fun and that's why I can recommend it. I'm having lots of fun playing this and it's worth the money.
